newsitem.title: ITALY: DPEF going in right direction - Italy's Bertinotti.
newsitem.headline: DPEF going in right direction - Italy's Bertinotti.

text.p: Italy's hard-left leader, the fiercest critic of any cuts in social spending, said on Thursday that the draft of the government's three-year economic plan appeared to be going in the right direction.

"We're waiting to see the final text tomorrow," Bertinotti told Reuters at the Chamber of Deputies (lower house) after parliamentary party leaders from the ruling centre-left alliance met the government earlier for talks on the document.

"I think there are, so to say, differences of approach, but we appreciate moves in the direction that we had hoped for, that is a different ratio between spending cuts and increased revenues and a greater focus on unemployment," he said.

Union sources say the document, called the DPEF, which the cabinet is due to approve on Friday, sets a 2.8 percent deficit-GDP ratio for 1998. Official sources say the government intends to make deficit cuts of 25 trillion lire next year.
Controversy has raged over how much of this should come from spending cuts, including on pensions and welfare spending.
Trades unions and Bertinotti's Communist Refoundation party, which ensures the government's parliamentary majority, are opposed to deep cuts.

Newspapers have reported that two-thirds of the 1998 deficit reductions would come from spending cuts and one-third from extra revenue but Maurizio Pieroni, Greens party Senate (upper house) leader, said on Thursday said the mix would be 60-40.
Bertinotti said the government forecast a fall in annual unemployment in the order of 0.7 percent. "This shows a reversal of the trend but obviously more can be done."
He also called for "a sign of a fight against tax fraud and above all to bring the question of pensions into the discussion on the welfare state without prejudicing the outcome".

But Bertinotti signalled no immediate softening of his opposition to welfare cuts. "We are going into these discussions with the position that is already well known, that is that pensions should be defended," he said.
